clinical_study.brief_title: Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy in Management of ACC Within and After 3 Days
clinical_study.official_title: Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy for Management of Acute Calculous Cholecystitis Within and After 3 Days of Disease Onset

brief_summary.textblock: This study was aimed to assess the outcome of laparoscopic cholecystectomy in acute calculous cholecystitis in terms of conversion rates, postoperative complications and length of hospital stay within and after 3 days of symptoms onset.

detailed_description.textblock:
Acute cholecystitis is an inflammatory process presenting with biliary colic that is unremitting and may persist for more than 1 day. Obstruction of the cystic duct by a gallstone is the initiating event that leads to distention, inflammation and edema of the gallbladder wall. When the gallbladder remains obstructed and secondary bacterial infection supervenes, an acute gangrenous cholecystitis develops and an abscess or empyema forms within the gallbladder. The perforation usually is contained in the sub-hepatic space by the omentum.
Early cholecystectomy performed within 2 to 3 days of presentation is preferred over interval or delayed cholecystectomy that is performed 6 to 10 weeks after initial medical therapy. About 20% of patients fail initial medical therapy and require surgery during the initial admission or before the end of the planned conservative period. Since last 20 years, increasing number of surgeons have favored a policy of early surgery. Several randomized studies have shown that performing early cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis is better than delayed cholecystectomy in terms of shorter hospital stay, better operative outcome. Though recovery from disease is earlier in early cholecystectomy group, both groups have similar operative morbidity and mortality rates. This study aims to evaluate the surgical outcomes of laparoscopic cholecystectomy for ACC within and after 3 days of symptoms onset.

primary_outcome.measure: Comparison between early and late laparoscopic cholecystectomy regarding Difficulty of operation
primary_outcome.description: compare the difficulty of laparoscopic cholecystectomy within and after 3 days of the onset of acute calculous cholecystitis, difficulty will be assessed by the rate of conversion to open cholecystitectomy

primary_outcome.measure: Comparison between early and late laparoscopic cholecystectomy regarding Operation time
primary_outcome.description: compare the needed intra-operative time for laparoscopic cholecystectomy within and after 3 days of the onset of acute calcular cholecystitis , time will be measured by hours

primary_outcome.measure: comparison between early and late laparoscopic cholecystectomy regarding post operative pain
primary_outcome.description: compare between laparoscopic cholecystectomy within and after 3 days of the onset of acute cholecystitis , regarding the presence and duration of post operative pain , pain will be measured on a scale from 1 to 10

primary_outcome.measure: comparison between early and late laparoscopic cholecystectomy regarding post operative bile leakage
primary_outcome.description: compare between laparoscopic cholecystectomy within and after 3 days of the onset of acute cholecystitis , regarding the presence of bile leakage

secondary_outcome.description: compare post-operative duration of hospital stay after laparoscopic cholecystectomy within and after 3 days of the onset of acute cholecystitis ,duration will be measured by post operative spent days in hospital

secondary_outcome.measure: presence of any wound complication by examining the wound
secondary_outcome.description: comparison between early and late laparoscopic cholecystectomy concerning the presence and rate of wound infection by clinical examination post-operative

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Abdominal pain characteristic of Acute Cholecystitis, Positive Murphy's sign, Total Leucocyte Count > 10,000/ uL, and (4) Ultra-sonographic evidence of Acute Calculous Cholecystitis.
2. Initial surgical management planned for immediate laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
3. Patients who are fit for laparoscopy and general anesthesia.
4. Patient who agree to provide short term outcome data and agree to provide contact information.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients with ultra-sonographic findings of common bile duct calculi, pancreatitis, gall bladder perforation, gall bladder gangrene or gall bladder abscess.
2. Patients with other associated abdominal pathology.
3. Patients with any previous abdominal surgery or any significant systemic disease.
4. Septic shock.
5. Pregnancy/ Breast-feeding mothers.
